{{lead rewrite|date=September 2009}} {{Inca civilization}}
==Hydraulic engineering== {{See also|Incan aqueducts}}
The builders of the empire planned and built impressive waterworks in their city centers, including [[canal]]s, [[fountain]]s, [[drainage]] systems and expansive [[irrigation]]. Inca's infrastructure and [[water supply]] system have been hailed as “the pinnacle of the architectural and engineering works of the Inca civilization”.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Kenneth R. Wright |author2=Jonathan M. Kelly |author3=Alfredo Valencia Zegarra. | title=Machu Picchu: Ancient Hydraulic Engineering | journal=Journal of Hydraulic Engineering | year=1997| volume=123 | issue=10 | pages= 838–843 | doi=10.1061/(ASCE)0733-9429(1997)123:10(838)}}</ref> Major Inca centers were chosen by experts who decided the site, its apportionment, and the basic layout of the city. In many cities we see great hydraulic engineering marvels. For example, in the city of [[Tipón|Tipon]], 3 irrigation canals diverted water from Rio [[Pukara]] to [[Tipón|Tipon]] which is about 1.35 km north for Tipon's terraces.<ref name=":14">{{Cite book|title=Ancient Water Technologies|last=Mays|first=Larry|publisher=Springer|year=2009|isbn=978-9048186310|location=New York|pages=188–197}}</ref> [[Tipón|Tipon]] also had natural springs that they built fountains for that supplied noble residents with water for non agricultural purposes.<ref name=":14" />
==Machu Picchu== In 1450, [[Machu Picchu]] was constructed.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://www.machupicchu.org/how_old_is_machu_picchu.htm|title=How Old is Machu Picchu|last=|first=|date=|website=Peru for Less|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> This date was determined and based off the [[Radiocarbon dating|Carbon 14 test]] results.<ref name=":10" /> The famous lost Inca city is an architectural remnant of a society whose understanding of civil and [[hydraulic engineering]] was advanced. Today, it is famously known for its remarkable preservation as well as the beauty of the building's architecture.<ref name="springer" /> The site is located 120 km northwest of Cuzco in the Urubamba river valley, Peru.<ref name="springer" /> At 2560 m above sea level, sitting atop a mountain, the city planners had to consider the steep slopes of the site as well as the humid and rainy climate.<ref name="springer" /> The Inca people built this site atop a hill which was terraced (most likely for agricultural purposes).<ref name="springer" /> In addition to terraces, Machu Picchu is composed of two additional basic architectural elements; elite residential compounds and religious structures.<ref name="springer" /> The site is full of staircases and sculpted rock, which were also important to their architecture and engineering practices.<ref name="springer" /> [[File:99 - Machu Picchu - Juin 2009.edit3.jpg|thumb|An example of Machu Picchu]] Making models out of clay before beginning to build, the city planners remained consistent with Inca architecture and laid out a city that separated the agriculture and urban areas.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Before construction began the engineers had to assess the spring and whether it could provide for all of the city’s anticipated citizens. After evaluating the water supply, the civil engineers designed a {{convert|2457|ft|m|adj=on}}-long [[canal]] to what would become the city’s center. The canal descends the mountain slope, enters the city walls, passes through the agricultural sector, then crosses the inner wall into the urban sector, where it feeds a series of fountains. The fountains are publicly accessible and partially enclosed by walls that are typically about 1.2 m high, except for the lowest fountain, which is a private fountain for the Temple of the Condor and has higher walls. At the head of each fountain, a cut stone conduit carries the water to a rectangular spout, which is shaped to create a jet of water suitable for filling aryballo–a typical Inca clay water jug. The water collects in a stone basin in the floor of the fountain, then enters a circular drain that delivers it to the approach channel for the next fountain.
The Incas built the canals on steady grades, using cut stones as the water channels. Most citizens worked on the construction and maintenance of the canal and irrigation systems, bronze and [[stone tool|stone]] tools to complete the water-tight stone canals. The water then traveled through the channels into sixteen [[fountain]]s known as the "stairway of fountains", reserving the first water source for the [[emperor]]. This incredible feat supplied the population of Machu Picchu, which varied between 300 and 1000 people when the emperor was present, and also helped irrigate water to the farming steppes. The fountains and canal system were built so well that they would, after a few minor repairs, still work today.
To go along with the Incas' advanced water supply system, an equally impressive drainage system was built as well. Machu Picchu contains nearly 130 outlets in the center that moved the water out of the city through walls and other structures. The agriculture [[Terrace (agriculture)|terraces]] are a feature of the complicated drainage system; the [[steppe]]s helped avoid erosion, and were built on a slope to aimed excess water into channels that ran alongside the stairways. These channels carried the runoff into the main drain, avoiding the main water supply. This carefully planned drainage system shows the Incas' concern and appreciation for clean water. Water engineer Ken Wright and his archaeological team found the emperor’s [[bathing room]] complete with a separate [[Drain (plumbing)|drain]] that carried off his used bath water so it would never re-enter Machu Picchu’s water supply.
== Terraces ==
=== Terrace Function and Structure === The Inca faced many problems with living in areas with steep terrain. Two large issues were soil [[erosion]] and area to grow crops.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/terrace-cultivation|title=Terrace cultivation|website=britannica.com|access-date=2017-01-16}}</ref><ref name=":9" /> The solution to these problems were the development of terraces, called [[Anden]]es. These terraces allowed the Inca to utilize land for farming that they never could in the past.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Londoño|first=Ana|date=February 12, 2007|title=Pattern and rate of erosion inferred from Inca agricultural terraces in arid southern Peru|journal=Geomorphology|volume=99|pages=13|doi=10.1016/j.geomorph.2007.09.014}}</ref> Everything about how the terrace function, looks, its geometric alignment, etc. all depend on the slope of the land.<ref name=":9" /> The different layering of materials is part of what makes the terraces so successful. It starts with a base layer of large rocks. Followed by a second layer is smaller rocks. Then a layer of sand like material, and finally the top soil. You can practice this in a simulation [http://nmai.si.edu/inkaroad/engineering/activity/engineer-inka-terrace.html here].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nmai.si.edu/inkaroad/engineering/activity/engineer-inka-terrace.html|title=Engineering the Inka empire|last=|first=|date=|website=Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The most impressive part of the terraces were their drainage systems.  Drain outlets placed in the numerous stone retaining walls.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Wright, Valencia, Lorah|first=Kenneth, Alfedo, William|date=|title=Ancient Machu Picchu Drainage Engineering|url=http://www.waterhistory.org/histories/machupicchu/machupicchu.pdf|journal=Waterhistory.org|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The larger rocks at base of each terrace level is what allowed the water to flow easier through the larger spaces in between the rocks eventually coming out at the “Main Drain”.<ref name=":13" /> The Inca even constructed different types of drainage channels that are used for different purposes throughout the city.  
=== How They Were Built and Why They Were Effective. === Studies have indicated that when terraces like the ones in the Colca Valley were being constricted the first step was excavating into the slope and the a subsequent infilling of the slope.<ref name=":9" /> A retaining wall was built to hold the fill material.<ref name=":13" /> This wall had many uses including absorbing heat from the sun during the day and radiated it back out at night, often keeping crops from freezing in the chilling nighttime temperatures and holding back the different layers of sediment. After the wall is built the larger rocks would be placed on the bottom, then smaller rocks, then sand, then soil.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":13" />
Since the soil was now level, the water did not rush down the side of the mountain which is what causes erosion. Previously, this erosion was so powerful that it had potential to wipe out major areas of the Inca road as well as and wash away all of the nutrients and fertile soil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nmai.si.edu/inkaroad/engineering/question/how-did-inka-control-erosion-and-grow-crops-steep-andes-terrain.html|title=How did the Inca control erosion and grow crops|last=|first=|date=June 26, 2010|website=Engineering the Inca empire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Since the soil never washed away, nutrients would always be added from previously grown crops year after year.<ref name=":9" /> The Inca even grew specific crops together to balance out the optimal amount of nutrients for all plants. For example, a planting method known as "three sisters" incorporated the growth of corn, beans and squash in the same terrace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://science.howstuffworks.com/innovation/inventions/5-ancient-incan-inventions4.htm|title=Terrace Farming|last=Franco|first=Michael|date=|website=HowStuffWorks|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> This was because the fixed nitrogen in the beans helped the corn grow while the squash acted as mulch keeping the soil moist and also acted as a weed repellant.
== Freeze -Drying ==
=== What to Freeze Dry and why? === A very common and well known Freeze dried item was the potato or when it was frozen, [[Chuño]].<ref name=":0" /> All food grown or killed by the [[Inca Empire|Inca]] could be [[Freeze-drying|freeze dried]]. Freeze drying is still very popular today. One of the biggest benefits for freeze drying is that it takes out all of the water and [[moisture]] but leaves all of the nutritious value.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://www.inside-peru.com/inca-food.html|title=Inca Food and the Inca People|last=Unknown|first=|date=Not stated|website=inside peru.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The water in meats and vegetables is what gives them a lot of their weight. This is what made it very popular for transportation purposes and storage because dried meats lasted twice as long as non freeze dried foods.<ref name=":0" />
Vegetables- Potato
Inca diet was largely [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian]] because large wild game were often reserved for special occasions.<ref name=":0" />
Meats- Llama, Alpaca, duck, guinea-pig<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":0" />
Transportation and storage of [[jerky]] Or 'charki' (the Inca name) was much easier to transport and lasted longer than not dried meats.<ref name=":0" /> These all had potential to be freeze dried.
==== How to Freeze dry ==== [[File:Chuño.jpg|thumb|Chuño]] Both meats and vegetables went through a similar freezing process. They would start by laying all the different foods on rocks and during the cold nights in high [[altitude]]s with dry air they would freeze.<ref name=":11" /> The next morning, a combination of the thin dry air and the heat from the sun would melt the ice and [[Evaporation|evaporate]] all the [[moisture]].<ref name=":11" /> The most important factor about this process and what made the Inca able to do this is the dry and [[google:rarefied&oq=rarefied&aqs=chrome..69i57j0l5.1614j1j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8|rarefied]] atmosphere that they live in. A few different methods can be used for the last step which is take out the last of the moisture. The over arching idea is to compress the food to a point where it would expel the rest of its moisture.
The process of Freeze Drying was important for transportation and storage.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":0" /> In the high elevation of the [[Andes|Andes Montanan's]] the low temperatures is a huge factor of what allowed them to take advantage of this process.
== Pathway Systems == The vast size of the [[Inca Empire|Inca empire]] made it essential that efficient and effective transportation systems were created and built to assist in the exchanging of goods, services, people, etc. At one point, "their (the [[Inca Empire|Inca) empire]] eventually extended across western South America from Quito in the north to Santiago in the south, making it the largest empire ever seen in the Americas and the largest in the world at that time (between c. 1400 and 1533 CE)."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ancient.eu/Inca_Civilization/|title=Inca Civilization|last=Cartwright|first=Mark|date=September 15, 2014|website=Ancient History Encyclopedia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 30, 2017}}</ref> It is known to have "extended some 3500-4000 km along the mountainous backbone of South America."<ref name="springer">{{Cite book|url=https://link-springer-com.muhlenberg.idm.oclc.org/content/pdf/10.1007%2F978-1-4615-0521-1_14.pdf|title=Encyclopedia of Prehistory: Volume 7: South America|last=Peregrine|first=Peter|last2=Ember|first2=Melvin|publisher=|year=2002|isbn=|location=|pages=150–193|url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://gridclub.com/subscribers/info/fact_gadget_2009/best_ever_qa/history/early_america/1678.html|title=Grid Club|last=powered by Google|first=|date=|website=Fact Gadget|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 1, 2017}}</ref> The trails, roads, and bridges were designed not only to link the empire physically, but these structures also helped the empire to maintain communication.
=== <u>Rope Bridges</u> === [[File:Inca bridge.jpg|thumb|An example of an Inca rope bridge]] [[Inca rope bridge|Rope bridges]] were an integral part of the [[Inca road system]]. "Five centuries ago, the [[Andes]] were strung with [[Inca rope bridge|suspension bridges]]. By some estimates there were as many as 200 of them."<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/atlas_obscura/2013/06/10/the_last_incan_suspension_bridge_is_made_entirely_of_grass_and_woven_by.html|title=The Last Incan Suspension Bridge Is Made Entirely of Grass and Woven by Hand|last=Obscura|first=Atlas|date=June 10, 2013|website=Slate|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 1, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/08/science/08bridg.html|title=How the Inca Leapt Canyons|last=Wilford|first=John|date=May 8, 2007|website=The New York Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> As pictured to the right, these structures were used to connect two land masses, allowing for the flow of ideas, goods, people, animals, etc. across the [[Inca Empire|Incan empire]]. "The [[Inca rope bridge|Inca suspension bridges]] achieved clear spans of at least 150 feet, probably much greater.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/education/ancient/grass-bridge.html|title=Grass Bridge|last=|first=|date=May 9, 2006|website=PBS|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> This was a longer span than any European masonry bridges at the time."<ref name=":3" /> Since the Incan people did not use wheeled vehicles, most traveled by foot and/or used animals to help in the transporting of goods.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" />
==== ''Construction'' ==== Although these [[Inca Bridge|bridges]] were assembled using twisted mountain grass, other vegetation, and saplings, they were dependable.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> These structures were able to both support the weight of traveling people and animals as well as withstand weather conditions over certain amounts of time. Since grass rots away over time, the bridges had to be rebuilt every year.<ref name=":4" /> [[File:2015 Smithsonian folklife festival DC -Qeswachaka Bridge rope making - 01.jpg|thumb|280x280px|Pictured is the weaving of grass into rope to be used in the formation of a bridge]] When the [[Inca Empire|Inca]] people began building a [[Inca Bridge|grass suspension bridge]], they would first gather natural materials of grass and other vegetation. They would then braid these elements together into rope. This contribution was made by the Inca women.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jh5mYw3PNhs|title=Inca Bridge|last=|first=|date=August 4, 2011|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Vast amounts of thin-looking rope were produced.<ref name=":5" /> The villagers would then deliver their quota of rope to the builders.<ref name=":5" /> The rope was then divided into sections.<ref name=":5" /> Each section consisted of an amount of thin rope being laid out together in preparation to create a thicker rope cord.<ref name=":5" /> Once the sections are laid out, the strands of rope made earlier are twisted together tightly and evenly, producing the larger and thicker rope cord.<ref name=":5" /> These larger ropes are then braided together to create cables, some as thick as a human torso.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /> Depending on the dimensions of the cable, each could weigh up to 200 pounds.<ref name=":5" /> These cables were then delivered to the bridge site.<ref name=":5" />
It was considered bad luck for women to be anywhere near the construction of the bridge, so the Inca men were therefore in charge of the on-site construction.<ref name=":4" /> At the bridge site, a builder(s) would travel to the opposite land mass that they were working to connect.<ref name=":5" /> Once they were positioned on the opposite side, one of the thin, light-weight ropes would be thrown over to them.<ref name=":5" /> This rope would then be used to pull the main cables over the gorge.<ref name=":5" /> Stone beams were built on either side of the gorge and were used in helping to position and secure the cables.<ref name=":5" /> The cables were wrapped around these stone beams and tightened inch by inch to decrease any slack in the bridge.<ref name=":5" /> Once this was finished, the riggers carefully made their way across the hanging cables, tying the foot-ropes together and connecting the handrails and the foot-ropes with the remainder of the thin grass ropes.<ref name=":5" /> Not all rope bridges were exactly alike in terms of design and build. Some riggers also wove pieces of wood into the foot-ropes.
Modern day rope bridge builders in Huinchiri, Peru make offerings to Pacha Mama, otherwise known as "Mother Earth," throughout their building process to ensure that the bridge will be strong and safe.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/transcripts/2404inca.html|title=SECRETS OF LOST EMPIRES: INCA|last=|first=|date=February 11, 1997|website=PBS|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> This may have been a practice used by the Inca people since they too were religious. If all went smoothly and if tasks were performed in a timely fashion, a bridge had the potential of being constructed in three days.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":12" />
==== ''Modern Rope Bridges'' ==== [[File:IRB-7-MUDDY2.jpg|thumb|280x280px|An example of a rope bridge]] People today continue to honor Incan traditions and expand their knowledge in the building of [[Inca rope bridge|rope bridges]].
1."Each June in Huinchiri, Peru, four [[Quechua people|Quechua]] communities on two sides of a gorge join together to build a bridge out of grass, creating a form of ancient infrastructure that dates back at least five centuries to the [[Inca Empire]]."<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://hyperallergic.com/281699/the-inca-rope-bridge-thats-woven-across-a-river-each-year/|title=The Inca Rope Bridge That’s Woven Across a River Each Year|last=Meier|first=Allison|date=March 31, 2016|website=Hyperallergic|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> The previous Q’eswachaka Bridge is cut down and swept away by the [[Apurímac River]] current and a new bridge is built in its place.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://festival.si.edu/2015/peru/traditional-knowledge/qeswachaka-bridge/smithsonian|title=Q’ESWACHAKA BRIDGE|last=|first=|date=2015|website=Smithsonian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> This tradition links the [[Quechua people|Quechua]] communities of the Huinchiri, Chaupibanda, Choccayhua, and Ccollana Quehue to their past ancestors.<ref name=":7" /> <blockquote>''“According to our grandfathers, this bridge was built during the time of the Inkas 600 years ago, and on it they walked their [[llama]]s and [[alpaca]]s carrying their produce.”'' ''-'' Eleuterio Ccallo Tapia<ref name=":7" /> </blockquote>2. "A small portion of a 60-foot replica built by [[Quechua people|Quechua]] weavers is on view in ''The Great Inka Road: Engineering an Empire ''at the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum|Smithsonian’s National Museum]] of the American Indian in Washington, DC."<ref name=":6" /> This exhibit will be on display at the museum through June 1, 2020.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/blogs/national-museum-american-indian/2017/08/05/qeswachaka-last-inka-suspension-bridge/|title=Q’eswachaka, the Last Inka Suspension Bridge|last=Plata|first=Allie|date=August 4, 2017|website=Smithsonian.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> Visitors are also encouraged to experience this exhibit online.<ref name=":8" /> Either way, museums like the Smithsonian are working to preserve and display examples and knowledge of the Inca inspired [[Inca rope bridge|rope bridges]] today.
3.  John Wilford shares in the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' that students at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] are learning much more than how objects are made. They are being taught to observe and test how archeology entwines with culture.<ref name=":3" /> Wilford's article was written in 2007.<ref name=":3" /> At this time, students involved in a course called “materials in human experience,” were busy making a 60-foot-long fiber bridge in the Peruvian style.<ref name=":3" /> Through this project, they were introduced to the Inca people's way of thinking and building.<ref name=":3" /> After creating their ropes and cables, they had planned to stretch the bridge across a dry basin between two campus buildings.<ref name=":3" />
=== <u>Roads</u> === [[File:Inca trail, Peru.jpg|thumb|This trail was originally constructed by the Inca in Peru. It is now part of the Inca trail to Machu Picchu.]] [[File:Camino-inca-dia4-c06.jpg|thumb|An example of the Inca trail from [[Cusco]] to [[Machu Picchu]] in [[Perú]].]] According to author Mark Cartwright, "[[Inca road system|Inca roads]] covered over 40,000 km (25,000 miles), principally in two main highways running north to south across the [[Inca Empire]], which eventually spread over ancient Peru, Ecuador, Chile, Bolivia, and Argentina."<ref name=":0" /> Several sources challenge Cartwright's claim in stating that the Inca roads covered either more or less area then he describes. This number is difficult to solidify since some of the pathways of the Inca still may remain unaccounted for, being that they may have been washed away or covered by natural forces. "Inca engineers were also undaunted by geographical difficulties and built roads across ravines, rivers, deserts, and mountain passes up to 5,000 metres high."<ref name=":0" /> Many of the constructed roads are not uniform in design.<ref name=":0" /> Most of the uncovered roads are about one to four meters wide.<ref name=":0" /> Although this is true, some roads, such as the highway in [[Huánuco Pampa|Huanuco Pampa]] province, can be much larger in size.<ref name=":0" /> As mentioned in the "Pathway Systems" section, the Inca people mainly traveled on foot. Knowing this, the roads created were most likely built and paved for both humans and animals to walk and/or run along. Several roads were paved with stones or cobbles and some were "edged and protected with the use of small stone walls, stone markers, wooden or cane posts, or piles of stones."<ref name=":0" /> Drainage was something that was of particular interest and importance to the Inca people. Drains and culverts were built to ensure that rainwater would effectively run off of the road's surface.<ref name=":0" /> The drains and culverts helped in directing the accumulating water either along or under the road.<ref name=":0" />
==== ''Uses'' ==== 1. As mentioned above under the section "Pathway Systems," there were several uses for the [[Inca road system|Inca roads]]. The most obvious way in which the [[Inca Empire|Inca]] people used the road/trail systems were to transport goods. They did this on foot and sometimes with the help of animals (llamas and alpacas).
2. Not only were goods transported throughout the vast [[Inca Empire|empire]], but so were ideas and messages. The Inca needed a system of communication, so they relied on [[Chasqui]]s, otherwise known as messengers.<ref name=":13x">{{Cite web|url=http://www.discover-peru.org/inca-roads-chasqui/|title=Inca Roads and Chasquis|last=|first=|date=|website=Discover Peru|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> The [[Chasqui]]s were chosen among the strongest and fittest young males.<ref name=":13x" /> They ran several miles per day, only to deliver messages.<ref name=":13x" /> These messengers resided in cabins called "[[Tambo (Incan structure)|tambos]]."<ref name=":13x" /> These structures were positioned along the roads and built by the Inca people.<ref name=":13x" /> These buildings provided the [[Chasqui]]s with a place to rest.<ref name=":13x" /> These places of rest could also be used to house the Inca army in a situation of rebellion or war.<ref name=":13x" />
==== ''Modern Inca Roads'' ==== Today, many travel to South America to hike the Inca trail.<ref name=":14x">{{Cite web|url=http://www.perutreks.com/inca_trail_to_machu_picchu.html|title=Inca Trail to Machu Picchu|last=|first=|date=|website=Peru Treks & Adventure|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> Walking and climbing the trail not only serves the purpose of allowing visitors to expirience the historic pathways of the Inca people, but it allows for tourists and locals to see the Inca ruins, mountains, and exotic vegetation and animals.<ref name=":14x" />

In studies of the [[public understanding of science]], the '''information deficit model''' (or simply '''deficit model''') or '''science literacy/knowledge deficit model''' attributes public scepticism or hostility to science and technology to a lack of understanding, resulting from a lack of information. It is associated with a division between experts who have the information and non-experts who do not. The model implies that communication should focus on improving the transfer of information from experts to non-experts.
==Deficit model of science communication==
The original term ‘deficit model’ was coined in the 1980s by [[social scientists]] studying the public communication of science. The purpose of the phrase was not to introduce a new mode of science communication but rather it was to characterise a widely held belief that underlies much of what is carried out in the name of such activity.
There are two aspects to this belief. The first is the idea that public uncertainty and scepticism towards modern science including environmental issues and technology is caused primarily by a lack of sufficient knowledge about science and the relevant subjects. The second aspect relates to the idea that by providing the adequate information to overcome this lack of knowledge, also known as a ‘knowledge deficit’, the general [[public opinion]] will change and decide that the information provided on the environment and science as a whole is reliable and accurate.<ref name="Dickson">Dickson, D. 2005. [http://www.scidev.net/global/communication/editorials/the-case-for-a-deficit-model-of-science-communic.html The Case for a ‘deficit model’ of science communication]. ''Science and Development Network''.</ref>
Scientists are often heard to complain that the general public does not understand science, and that the public needs to be educated. In the deficit model scientists assume that there is a knowledge deficit that can be ‘fixed’ by giving the public more information: scientists often assume that “given the facts (whatever they are), the public will happily support new technologies.”<ref name="Brown">Brown, S. 2009. [http://www.nature.com/nnano/journal/v4/n10/full/nnano.2009.278.html The new deficit model]. ''Nature Nanotechnology'' '''4''':609-611.</ref>
The deficit model, however, has been discredited by a wealth of literature that shows that simply giving more information to people does not necessarily change their views.<ref>Kearnes M., Macnaghten P. & Wilsdon, J. Governing at the Nanoscale (Demos, 2006); available at <{{cite web |url=http://www.demos.co.uk/publications/governingatthenanoscale |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214083000/http://www.demos.co.uk/publications/governingatthenanoscale |archivedate=2007-12-14 |df= }}>.</ref> This is partly because people want to feel that they have had their say (and have been heard) in any decision-making process, and partly because people make decisions based on a host of factors as well as the scientific ‘facts’. These factors include [[ethical]] and religious beliefs, in addition to culture, history and personal experience. This amounts to a kind of gut feeling, which scientific facts are unlikely to change. Put another way, people’s sense of risk extends beyond the purely scientific considerations of conventional risk analysis, and the deficit model marginalises these ‘[[externalities]]’. It is now widely accepted that the best alternative to deficit model thinking is to genuinely engage with the public and take these externalities into account.<ref>Boykoff, MT (2009), Creating a Climate for Change: Communicating Climate Change and Facilitating Social Change. Glob. Environ. Polit. 9 (2) 123-128</ref>
The deficit model sees the general population as the receiver of information and scientific knowledge. The information they receive, through whatever medium, has been prearranged to inform them of information that the distributors believe to be in the public’s interest. Due to the recent growth of scientific research and subsequent discoveries, the deficit model suggests that this has led to a decrease in interest surrounding certain areas of science. This can be down to the public feeling overwhelmed with information and becomes uninterested, as it appears too much to take in.
The deficit model of scientific understanding makes assumptions about the public’s knowledge. The model perceives them to be “blank slates” where their knowledge of scientific discourse and research is almost non-existent.<ref>Gregory, Jane and Miller, Steve (2000), Science in Public: Communication, Culture and Credibility, (London: Perseus)</ref> Again, this is the knowledge deficit that needs to be informed by a reliable, knowledgeable and hierarchical scientific community in the form of simple commands and generic instructions. But the increase in new information systems such as the Internet and their ease of accessibility has led to a greater knowledge of scientific research and this is evident as the public’s understanding can be seen to be growing.{{Citation needed|reason=Can this statement be validated?|date=August 2017}} This is a good thing in terms of the members of the public that can actively increase their own knowledge base, decrease the knowledge deficit and assess the truth and validity of what [[mass media]] outlets and [[governments]] are telling them. This should enhance and increase the relationship between the passive “blank slates” of the public, with the minority of the population who hold the ‘knowledge surplus’.
===Evidence for a deficit affecting opinion=== A 420 meta-analysis of 193 studies sought to interpret the link between science knowledge and attitude towards science.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Allum|first1=Nick|author2=Sturgis P, Tabourazi D, Brunton-Smith I|title=Science knowledge and attitudes across cultures: a meta-analysis|journal=Public Understanding of Science|date=2008|volume=17|pages=35–54|doi=10.1177/0963662506070159}}</ref> The studies included were taken using nonuniform methods across the world between 1989 and 2004 to provide a cross-cultural analysis. Broad and specific science knowledge and attitude categories were correlated. General science and general biology knowledge was gauged using questions similar to those by the [[National Science Foundation]] used to capture "civil scientific literacy".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Miller|first=J.D.|title=Scientific Literacy: a Conceptual and Empirical Review|journal=Dedalus|date=1983|volume=11|pages=29–48}}</ref> Data on general science and biology knowledge was then compared with attitudes towards general science, nuclear power, genetic medicine, [[genetically modified food]], and environmental science. From the raw data, it was found that a small positive correlation exists between general science knowledge and attitude towards science, indicating that increased scientific knowledge is related to a favorable attitude towards a science topic, and that this was not related to socioeconomic or technologic status of a country, but rather the number of individuals enrolled in tertiary education. However, some studies have found that high levels of science knowledge may indicate highly positive and highly negative attitudes towards specific topics such as agriculture [[biotechnology]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Durant |first=J. |title=Biotechnology in Public: a Review of Recent Research|publisher=Science Museum Publications|date=1992|location=London|pages=28–41|author2=Martin, S Tait, J.|authorlink=Attitudes of Selected Public Groups in the UK to Biotechnology}}</ref> Thus knowledge may be a predictor of the attitude strength and not necessarily if the attitude is positive or negative.
==The role of the media==
[[Mass media]] representations, ranging from news to entertainment, are critical links between the everyday realities of how people experience certain issues and the ways in which these are discussed at a distance between science, policy and public actors.<ref name="Dickson"/> Numerous studies show that the public frequently learn about science and more specifically issues such as climate change from the mass media.
There is perceived to be a trend within much of the world’s media that a traditional commitment to report the full facts is and has given way to a more obvious, less reliable tendency to concentrate coverage on interpretations of the facts. This so-called ‘spin’ is reported by the world’s press under a combination of commercial and political pressure. This can be dangerous as it ‘fills’ the knowledge deficit and the unsuspecting public with sometimes unreliable, agenda promoting information. The subjects of anthropogenic [[global warming]] and [[climate change]] are at the forefront of this. However, in all cases it is becoming increasingly difficult to separate out the factual basis of what is being reported from the ‘spin’ that is exerted on the way a story is reported and presented.<ref name="Brown"/>
The mass media is accessible to the vast numbers of the global population and ranging from entertainment, to news media, and spanning books, films, televisions, newspapers, radio, games and the Internet. More modern forms of communication and receiving of information have given the public a much wider and accessible format in which to gain knowledge themselves.
The actual processes behind the communication and dissemination of information from the experts to the public may be far more complex and deep running than the deficit model suggests.
The knowledge deficit model is important for science communicators to know about. This is particularly important with respect to the concept of [[framing (social sciences)|framing]] when communicating information. Framing can be used to reduce the complexity of an issue, or to persuade audiences, and can play into the underlying religious beliefs, moral values, prior knowledge, and even trust in scientists or political individuals. Further, the transmission of scientific ideas and technological adoption may be strongly linked to the passage of information between easily influenced individuals,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Watts|first1=Duncan J. |author2=Dodds, P.S.|title=Influentials, Networks, and Public Opinion Formation|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|date=2007|volume=34|pages=441–458|doi=10.1086/518527}}</ref> versus the widely accepted "two-step flow" theory where a few opinion leaders acted as intermediaries between mass media and the general public.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Katz |first1=Eliju|author2=Lazersfeld, P.F.|title=Personal Influence; the Part Played by People in the Flow of Mass Communication|date=1955}}</ref> Decreasing the knowledge deficit is a complicated task, but if we know how the general public thinks, or how they go about learning and interpreting new information, we can better communicate our message to them in the most unbiased, objective way possible.<ref>{{cite book |last=Scheufele |first=Dietram |title=MESSAGES AND HEURISTICS: HOW AUDIENCES FORM ATTITUDES ABOUT EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES|location=Engaging Science: Thoughts, deeds, analysis and action|pages=21–25}}</ref>
==Alternative models== In contrast to the knowledge-deficit model is the [[low-information rationality]] model that states humans minimize costs associated with making decisions and forming attitudes, thereby avoiding developing in-depth understandings.
== See also == * [[Cultural cognition]] * [[Low-information rationality]] * [[Thinking, Fast and Slow]]

A '''[[biobank]]''' is a physical place which stores [[biobank specimens]]. In some cases, participant data is also collected and stored. Access policies details may vary across biobanks but generally involve obtaining [[ethics]] approval from [[institutional review board]]s and scientific review or [[peer review]] approval from the institutions under which the biobanks operate as well as Ethics approval from the institutions where the research projects will be undertaken. The samples and data are safeguarded so that researchers can use them in experiments deemed adequate. This page contains a list of biobanks.
==Classification== Biobanks can be classified in several ways. Some examples of how they can be classified is by their controlling entity (government, commercial enterprise, or private research institution), by their geographical location, or by what sorts of samples they collect.
Biobanks may be classified by purpose or design. Disease-oriented biobanks usually have a hospital affiliation through which they collect samples representing a variety of diseases, perhaps to look for biomarkers affiliated with disease.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bevilacqua | first1 = G. | last2 = Bosman | first2 = F. | last3 = Dassesse | first3 = T. | last4 = Höfler | first4 = H. | last5 = Janin | first5 = A. | last6 = Langer | first6 = R. | last7 = Larsimont | first7 = D. | last8 = Morente | first8 = M. '''Mary E. (Ellen) Williamson''' (1924–2012) served as a WASP ([[Women Airforce Service Pilots]]) during [[World War II]] and was a [[Communication studies|communications professor]] at the [[University of Nebraska Omaha]].<ref name=Grave>{{cite web|last1=Bender|first1=Loren|title=Mary Ellen Williamson|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/102474616|website=Find a Grave|accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=WAP>{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Angelika|title=Mary Williamson|url=http://wap.lib.unomaha.edu/mwilliamson.html|website=Women’s Archive Project|accessdate=31 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150613204622/http://wap.lib.unomaha.edu/mwilliamson.html|archivedate=13 June 2015|df=}}</ref>
==Early life, education and military service== Mary E. Williamson was born on April 24, 1924, in [[Kansas City, Missouri]], to Elmer C. Williamson and Ruth Peterman Williamson.<ref name="Grave" /> Mary was an only child, whom her mother Ruth raised on her own. The two remained very close throughout her life.<ref name="WAP" />
Williamson decided to attend [[Baker University]] after high school in 1941, but soon transferred to the [[Missouri School of Journalism]] at the [[University of Missouri]] in [[Columbia, Missouri]]. She finished this two-year program quickly and left for Sweetwater, Texas, in April 1944 to train as a pilot in the WASP ([[Women Air Force Service Pilots]]) program.<ref name="WAP" /> She served from April 1 to September 1, 1944, but never served on a mission before the war came to an end.<ref name="Grave" /><ref name="WAP" />
==Career== After her discharge, Williamson returned to Kansas City and acquired a job as the public relations director for the Kansas City Tuberculosis Society. Through this position, she was offered an opportunity to further her education, and eventually went on to obtain her master's degree from [[Columbia University]] in New York. After graduating, Williamson moved to Washington D.C., and took a job as an editor. However, wanting to be closer to her home, Williamson returned to St. Louis and accepted a position in broadcasting.<ref name="WAP" /><ref name=reflections>{{cite web|last1=Newton|first1=John|title=Reflections in Time Dr. Mary E. Williamson Interview|url=http://unomaha.worldcat.org/oclc/52643375|website=Reflections in Time|publisher=University of Nebraska at Omaha|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
Williamson began teaching in the Department of Speech and Mass communication at the [[University of Nebraska Omaha]] (UNO) in 1969.<ref name="Grave" /><ref name="WAP" /> Her first year at UNO Williamson taught courses such as Speech 101, Introduction to Mass Communications, Television Production and Radio Production. Williamson also served as [[PanHellenic]] advisor to the Greek communities on campus.<ref name=gateway1976>{{cite news|last1=Kurtz|first1=Terry|title=Greek Life Analyzed to Update '50s Image|url=http://digital.olivesoftware.com/olive/apa/unomaha/SharedView.Article.aspx?href=GTW%2F1976%2F10%2F22&id=Ar00400&sk=AD66CB0E|accessdate=31 March 2015|publisher=The Gateway|date=22 October 1976}}</ref>
Williamson finished her doctoral program in 1973 with the publication of her thesis "An Inquiry into Excellence in Commercial Broadcasting". Williamson incorporated work experience with the Nebraska Business Development Center (NBDC) in many of her courses, so that students were able to provide services and advice to small business owners in the Omaha area.
Throughout her time at UNO, Williamson served in various roles across campus. She was elected to Faculty Senate and served her second term as Vice President in 1977 and then as President in 1978.<ref name="Grave" /><ref name="WAP" /> During this service, she successfully removed gendered language from UNO's diploma despite some strong opposition. (7) Williamson served as the executive assistant to UNO Chancellor Del Weber from 1980 until 1986. Also in this time period, she was appointed Interim Dean for the College of Fine Arts for two years and later as the Interim University Relations Director, where she was responsible for public outreach for the university.<ref name="WAP" /><ref name=morewomen>{{cite news|last1=Peterson|first1=Marge|title=More Women Rank High at UNO|url=http://digital.olivesoftware.com/olive/apa/unomaha/SharedView.Article.aspx?href=GTW%2F1981%2F02%2F06&id=Ar00500&sk=C47EE9D5|accessdate=31 March 2015|publisher=The Gateway|date=6 February 1981}}</ref><ref name="Williamson Appointed">{{cite news|title=Williamson Appointed to Aid UNO Chancellor Weber|url=http://digital.olivesoftware.com/olive/apa/unomaha/SharedView.Article.aspx?href=GTW%2F1981%2F01%2F16&id=Ar00301&sk=520BFC36|publisher=The Gateway|date=16 January 1981}}</ref> After her interim stints in both departments, Williamson returned to the Communications Department as acting department chair. She took partial retirement shortly after and began working closely with NBDC as a business consultant.<ref name="WAP" /> Williamson retired in 2004 after 35 years of teaching at UNO.<ref name="Grave" /><ref name="WAP" />
In 1981, Williamson became an associate of the [[Women's Institute for Freedom of the Press]] (WIFP).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wifp.org/who-we-are/associates/|title=Associates {{!}} The Women’s Institute for Freedom of the Press|website=www.wifp.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> WIFP is an American nonprofit publishing organization. The organization works to increase communication between women and connect the public with forms of women-based media.
==Community service== Williamson also worked as the Vice President of Nebraska Cable Television and was later appointed by the mayor of Omaha to the community's Cable Television Advisory Committee for two terms.
After retirement she remained active around Omaha by filling a volunteer capacity in various organizations. Williamson served as an [[ombudsman]] at the Ambassador Rehabilitation Center, a counselor at the [[Service Corps of Retired Executives]] (SCORE), and assisted the Hearts United for Animals shelter.<ref name="Grave" /><ref name="WAP" />
==Awards== Williamson received recognition for her service to the Faculty Senate in the 1970s and a certificate from the University of Nebraska Board of Regents in 1982 for her dedication to improving UNO. NBDC presented Williamson with the UNO Small Business Institute Award in 1987 and 1990 and then an award for her contribution to the Nebraska Small Business Community in 1992. Chancellor Nancy Belck presented Williamson with a plaque recognizing her service and devotion to UNO upon retirement. In 2007, the United Way of Midlands honored Williamson for her services and time, and she also received a certificate from her time as ombudsman at the Ambassador Rehabilitation Center.<ref name="Grave" /><ref name="WAP" />
In 2010, at the age of 86, Williamson was awarded the [[Congressional Gold Medal]] for her service as a Women Airforce Service Pilot (WASP) in Washington, D.C.<ref name=WWII>{{cite news|last1=Hovey|first1=Art|title=WWII Women Pilots Get Belated Recognition|url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/wwii-women-pilots-get-belated-recognition/article_18f95106-768a-11df-bb07-001cc4c002e0.html|accessdate=31 March 2015|agency=Lincoln Journal Star|date=12 June 2010}}</ref>
==Death== Williamson died on December 3, 2012, at age 88.<ref name="Grave" />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://unomaha-public.lyrasistechnology.org/repositories/4/resources/392 Finding aid for the Mary E. Williamson Papers], Archives & Special Collections, Criss Library, [[University of Nebraska at Omaha]]. * [http://unomaha.worldcat.org/oclc/52643375 Reflections in Time: Dr. Mary E. Williamson] interview, [[University of Nebraska at Omaha]], December 2002.

The '''{{Lang|fr|Méthode pour la guitare}}''' is a method for the [[classical guitar]] originally written in French by guitarist and composer [[Fernando Sor]].
The method was written with the early romantic guitar in mind (Sor mentions some 19th-century guitar-builders: J. Panormo, Schroeder of Petersburg, Alonso of Madrid, Pages and Benitez of Cadiz, Joseph and Manuel Martinez of Malaga, Rada, and Lacôte of Paris), but it is not only about instrumental technique, but also includes details about the theory of [[Scale (music)|scales]], [[harmony]], [[wiktionary:sonority|sonority]], composition, and above all music as an art.
==French and German edition==
[[File:Sor Methode.png|thumb|''Méthode pour la guitare'']] The first edition was in French and appeared in Paris in 1830 with the title of ''{{lang|fr|Méthode pour la guitare par Ferdinand Sor}}''.<ref>[http://bdh.bne.es/bnesearch/detalle/3276952 ''Méthode pour la guitare par Ferdinand Sor'' (1830)], [[Biblioteca Nacional de España]]</ref> Brian Jeffery (the modern publisher of A. Merrick's old English translation) mentions: "It is the only version known to have Sor's direct authority. Now extremely rare, it was never reprinted; indeed, an early biographer of Sor (Baltasar Saldoni in his ''Diccionario de Efemérides de Músicos Españoles'', I, Madrid, 1868) says (he does not state on what authority) that Sor destroyed the plates."<ref name="jeff" /> During the same period [[Nikolaus Simrock|Simrock]] in Bonn had brought out a parallel French and German edition.<ref>[http://www2.kb.dk/elib/noder/rischel/RiBS0788.pdf ''Méthode pour la guitare = Guitarre-Schule''] (Bonn: [[Nikolaus Simrock|N. Simrock]], 1831)</ref>
==English edition==
The English edition is a translation from the original in French made by A. Merrick, the organist of [[Cirencester]], and published in London by Cocks & Co. probably in 1832, as ''Method for the Spanish Guitar''. <ref>[http://bdh.bne.es/bnesearch/detalle/3275624 ''Method for the Spanish Guitar''], [[Biblioteca Nacional de España]]</ref> The French and German versions do not carry the word "Spanish" in the title. This version is today available from Brian Jeffery's.<ref>[http://www.tecla.com/catalog/0389.htm Fernando Sor – ''Method for the Spanish Guitar'' (1832)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407211504/http://www.tecla.com/catalog/0389.htm |date=2010-04-07 }}, Tecla Editions</ref>
Brian Jeffery mentions: "Later in the century, in 1897, Frank Mott Harrison published in London a ''Method for the Guitar'' by Ferdinando Sor,<ref>http://www.muslib.se/ebibliotek/boije/pdf/Boije%201140.pdf</ref> a work of small value which says (of course wrongly) that the original was written in Spanish."<ref name="jeff">{{cite web|url=http://www.tecla.com/extras/0001/0389/0389pref.htm|title=Sor: Method for the Spanish Guitar – preface to the Tecla edition | author = Brian Jeffery | publisher=Tecla}}</ref>
==Coste's adapted and augmented version==
After Sor's death, [[Napoléon Coste]], one of his pupils, published a revision of the original called ''{{lang|fr|Méthode complète pour la Guitare par Ferdinand Sor, rédigée et augmentée de nombreux exemples et leçons par N. Coste}}''.<ref>http://www2.kb.dk/elib/noder/rischel/RiBS0789.pdf [http://www2.kb.dk/elib/noder/rischel/RiBS0790.pdf alt.]</ref> Matanya Ophee states that in Coste's revised and augmented version, there is an introduction which is helpful in better understanding Sor, and some of the circumstances under which Sor wrote the original method.<ref name="ophee">{{cite web|url=http://www.guitarandluteissues.com/methods/methods.htm|title=A Brief History of Spanish Guitar Methods | author = Matanya Ophee | publisher=Éditions Orphée}}</ref>
Brian Jeffery controversially regards Coste's version somewhat negatively ("travesty of the original ... bears little resemblance to the original"),<ref name="jeff" /> even though the title immediately makes it clear, that it is not the original, but was adapted and augmented by Coste (augmented incidentally, with numerous pieces of high quality). Today Coste's version is highly regarded in its own right (the title mentioning of Sor, possibly being more a sign of respect, than what Jeffery has termed "a disservice to his friend's memory"). Ophee has written: "He [Coste] is certainly not hostile to Sor and to his memory".<ref name="ophee" />
==Various details== In the method (in plate VII, example 27), Sor quotes bars 22 to 25 of Sonata Op. 35, No. 1 by [[Jan Ladislav Dussek]]; mentioning "that the celebrated Düssek had the texture of the orchestra in view when he wrote for the pianoforte the passage in example twenty-seventh, plate VII."
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=aw0tAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA163&dq=Sor ''Seven years of the King's theatre''] by [[John Ebers]]; published by Carey, Lea & Carey, 1828 *[https://books.google.com/books?id=SRy2AAAAIAAJ&pg=RA2-PT87&dq=ferdinand+sor&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1780&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=1900&as_brr=3 ''Bibliographie de la France''] by [[Adrien-Jean-Quentin Beuchot]], Cercle de la librairie (France); publisher: Au Cercle de la Librairie, 1851 *[https://books.google.com/books?id=T_Y4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA557&dq=%22Ferdinand+Sor%22 ''Recensionen: Guitarre-Schule von Ferdinand Sor''], ''[[Allgemeine musikalische Zeitung]]''; published by [[Breitkopf & Härtel]], 1832 *[https://books.google.com/books?id=NHspAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA261&dq=%22Fernando+Sor%22 ''Diccionario biográfico-bibliográfico de efemérides de músicos españoles''] by Baltasar Saldoni

{{distinguish|text=[[Necrophila]], a genus of beetles}} {{Infobox medical condition | Name = Necrophilia | Image =Pietro Pajetta - Der Hass - 1896.jpeg | Caption =''The Hatred'', painted by [[Pietro Pajetta]], 1896. | Field = [[Psychiatry]] | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|F|65.8}} }} '''Necrophilia''', also known as '''necrophilism''', '''necrolagnia''', '''necrocoitus''', '''necrochlesis''', and '''thanatophilia''',{{sfn|Aggrawal|2016|p=1}} is a [[sexual attraction]] or sexual act involving [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by [[ICD10]] published by [[WHO]] and the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]]'' (DSM) of the [[American Psychiatric Association]].<ref name="goodwin">{{cite book|editor1-first=Robin|editor1-last=Goodwin|editor2-first=Duncan|editor2-last=Cramer|title=Inappropriate Relationships: The Unconventional, the Disapproved, and the Forbidden|pages=174–176|publisher=Psychology Press|location=London, England|date=2002|ISBN= 978-0805837421}}</ref>
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess a non-resisting and non-rejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref name="rosman">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = P. J. | date = 1 June 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = http://www.jaapl.org/content/17/2/153.full.pdf+html?sid=94a1e953-67b0-44c0-95a6-75ee304d916e | format=PDF/HTML| journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | publisher=[[American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law]]|location=Bloomfield, Connecticut|volume = 17 | issue = 2| pages = 153–163 | pmid = 2667656 }}</ref>
==Origins of term== The term 'necrophilia' is thought to have been coined by Belgian physician [[Joseph Guislain]] in his ''Leçons Orales sur les Phrénopathies'', in a lecture given around 1850, in reference to contemporary necrophile [[François Bertrand]]:<ref>Aggrawal p.4</ref> {{quote|It is within the category of the destructive madmen [''aliénés destructeurs''] that one needs to situate certain patients to whom I would like to give the name of necrophiliacs [''nécrophiles'']. The alienists have adopted, as a new form, the case of Sergeant Bertrand, the disinterrer of cadavers on whom all the newspapers have recently reported. However, don't think that we are dealing here with a form of phrenopathy which appears for the first time. The ancients, in speaking about [[lycanthropy]], have cited examples to which one can more or less relate the case which has just attracted the public attention so strongly.}} The term was popularized about a decade later by psychiatrist [[Bénédict Morel]], who also discussed Bertrand.<ref name="goodwin" />
==History== In the ancient world, sailors returning corpses to their home country were often accused of necrophilia.{{sfn|Aggrawal|2016|p=2}} Singular accounts of necrophilia in history are sporadic, though written records suggest the practice was present within [[Ancient Egypt]]. [[Herodotus]] writes in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, ancient [[Egypt]]ians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Herodotus (c. 440 BC) |title=The Histories (Book 2) |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/2707 |quote=The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brill | first1 = Abraham A. | date= 1941 | title = Necrophilia | journal = Journal of Criminal Psychopathology | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 433–443 }}</ref><ref name="klaf">{{cite journal |first1=Franklin S.|last1=Klaf |first2=William|last2=Brown |date= 1958 | title = Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report | journal = Psychiatric Quarterly | volume = 32 | issue = 4 | pages = 645–652 | quote = Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophiliac fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized. | doi=10.1007/bf01563024}}</ref> Herodotus also alluded to suggestions that Greek tyrant [[Periander]] had defiled the corpse of his wife, employing a metaphor: "Periander baked his bread in a cold oven."<ref>{{cite book | first=Anil |last= Aggrawal| date = 2010 | title = Necrophilia: Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects | publisher = CRC Press |location=Boca Raton, Florida| ISBN= 978-1420089127|pages = 6–7|quote=The primary source is ''Histories'', Book V, 92}}</ref> Acts of necrophilia are depicted on ceramics from the [[Moche (culture)|Moche]] culture, which reigned in northern [[Peru]] from the first to eighth century CE.<ref>{{cite book |first=Steve|last=Finbow | date = 2014 | title = Grave Desire: A Cultural History of Necrophilia | publisher = John Hunt Publishing | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rGIpBQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT4&ots=74OrhG8hA4&pg=PT39}}</ref> A common theme in these artifacts is the masturbation of a male skeleton by a living woman.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Weismantel, M. | year = 2004 | title = Moche sex pots: Reproduction and temporality in ancient South America | journal = American Anthropologist | volume = 106 | issue = 3 | pages = 495–496 | url = http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/moche/moche-sex-pots.pdf | doi=10.1525/aa.2004.106.3.495}}</ref> [[Hittites|Hittite]] law from the 16th century BC through to the 13th century BC explicitly permitted sex with the dead.<ref>{{cite book | author = Boer, Roland | year = 2014 | title = Sex in Antiquity: Exploring Gender and Sexuality in the Ancient World | chapter = From Horse Kissing to Beastly Emissions: Paraphilias in the Ancient Near East | editor = Masterson, Mark | publisher = Routledge | page = 69 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=k1G2BQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA69&ots=DtUbHRO19Dlr&pg=PA69#v=onepage}}</ref> In what is now [[Northeast China]], the ethnic [[Xianbei]] emperor [[Murong Xi]] (385–407) of the [[Later Yan]] state had intercourse with the corpse of his beloved empress [[Fu Xunying]], after the latter was already cold and put into the coffin.<ref>{{cite book|title=Tales about Chinese Emperors: Their Wild and Wise Ways|chapter=The Corpse-Raping Emperor|last=Luan Pao-chün|year=1994|pages=148–?|isbn=|publisher=Hai Feng Publishing Company}}</ref>
In [[Renaissance Italy]], following the reputed moral collapse brought about by the [[Black Death]] and before the [[Roman Inquisition]] of the [[Counter-Reformation]], the literature was replete with sexual references; these include necrophilia, in the case of the epic poem ''[[Orlando Innamorato]]'' by [[Matteo Maria Boiardo]], first published in 1483.<ref name="DavidsonDean1994">{{cite journal|last1=Davidson|first1=Nicholas|last2=Dean|first2=Trevor|last3=Lowe|first3=K. J. P.|title=Theology, nature and the law: sexual sin and sexual crime in Italy from the fourteenth to the seventeenth century|year=1994|pages=74–98|doi=10.1017/CBO9780511523410.006}}</ref> In a notorious modern example, American [[serial killer]] [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] was a necrophiliac. Dahmer wanted to create a [[sex slave]] that would mindlessly consent to whatever he wanted. When his attempts failed, and his male victim died, he would keep the corpse until it decomposed beyond recognition, continuously masturbating and performing sexual intercourse on the body.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.comicextra.com/my-friend-dahmer/chapter-Full/214|title=My Friend Dahmer #Full - Read My Friend Dahmer Issue #Full Page 214|website=www.comicextra.com|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref> In order to be aroused, he had to murder his male victims before performing sexual intercourse with them. Dahmer stated that he only killed his victims because they wanted to leave after having sex, and would be angry with him for drugging them.<ref>{{cite web|title=Psychiatric Testimony of Jeffrey Dahmer|url=http://www.criminalprofiling.com/Psychiatric-Testimony-of-Jeffrey-Dahmer_s115.html|work=Court Transcripts|publisher=Criminal Profiling|date=8 June 2001|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> British serial killer [[Dennis Nilsen]] is also considered to have been a necrophiliac.<ref>{{cite book | author = Masters, Brian | year = 1985 | title = Killing For Company | publisher = Arrow | isbn = 978-0099552611}}</ref>
==Classification== In the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]], fifth edition ([[DSM-5]]), recurrent, intense sexual interest in corpses can be diagnosed under [[Other Specified Paraphilic Disorder]] (necrophilia) when it causes marked distress or impairment in important areas of functioning.<ref name="DSM-5">{{cite book | title = Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition | chapter = Other Specified Paraphilic Disorder, 302.89 (F65.89) | editor = American Psychiatric Association | year = 2013 | publisher = American Psychiatric Publishing | page = 705}}</ref> A ten-tier classification of necrophilia exists:<ref name="aggrawal_classification">{{cite journal |author=Aggrawal, Anil |title=A new classification of necrophilia |journal=Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine |volume=16 |issue=6 |pages=316–20 |year=2009 |pmid=19573840 |doi=10.1016/j.jflm.2008.12.023 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1752928X08002564}} {{subscription required}}</ref> # Role players: People who get aroused from [[Sexual roleplay|pretending]] their live partner is dead during sexual activity. # Romantic necrophiliacs: Bereaved people who remain attached to their dead lover's body. # Necrophilic fantasizers: People who fantasize about necrophilia, but never actually have sex with a corpse. # Tactile necrophiliacs: People who are aroused by touching or stroking a corpse, without engaging in intercourse. # [[Sexual fetishism|Fetishistic]] necrophiliacs: People who remove objects (e.g., panties or a tampon) or body parts (e.g., a finger or genitalia) from a corpse for sexual purposes, without engaging in intercourse. # Necromutilomaniacs: People who derive pleasure from mutilating a corpse while masturbating, without engaging in intercourse. # Opportunistic necrophiliacs: People who normally have no interest in necrophilia, but take the opportunity when it arises. # Regular necrophiliacs: People who preferentially have intercourse with the dead. # Homicidal necrophiliacs: Necrosadists,{{sfn|Purcell|2006|p=21}} people who commit [[lust murder|murder]] in order to have sex with the victim. # Exclusive necrophiliacs: People who have an exclusive interest in sex with the dead, and cannot perform at all for a living partner. Additionally, criminologist [[Lee Mellor]]'s typology of homicidal necrophiles consists of eight categories (A–H), and is based on the combination of two behavioral axes: destructive (offender [[Mutilation|mutilates]] the corpse for sexual reasons) – preservative (offender does not), and cold (offender used the corpse sexually two hours after death) – warm (offender used the corpse sexually earlier than two hours after death).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Homicide: A Forensic Psychology Casebook|last=Mellor|first=Lee|publisher=CRC|year=2016|isbn=|location=Boca Raton, FL|pages=103–105}}</ref> This renders four categories (A-D) to which Mellor adds an additional four (E-H): * Category A (cold/destructive), e.g. [[Ted Bundy]], [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] * Category B (cold/preservative), e.g. [[Gary Ridgway]], [[Dennis Nilsen]] * Category C (warm/destructive) e.g. [[Andrei Chikatilo]], [[Joseph Vacher]] * Category D (warm/preservative) e.g. [[Robert Lee Yates|Robert Yates]], [[Earle Nelson]] * Category E (dabblers) e.g. [[Richard Ramirez]], [[Mark Dixie]] * Category F ([[Fredric Wertham|catathymic]]){{clarify|date=November 2018}} * Category G (exclusive necromutilophiles) e.g. [[Robert Napper]], [[Peter Sutcliffe]] * Category H (sexual [[Human cannibalism|cannibals]] & vampires) e.g. [[Albert Fish]], [[Peter Kürten]]<ref name=":0" /> Dabblers have transitory opportunistic sexual relations with corpses, but this is not their preference. Category F homicidal necrophiles commit postmortem sex acts only while in a [[Fredric Wertham|catathymic]] state. Exclusive mutilophiles derive pleasure purely from mutilating the corpse, while sexual [[Human cannibalism|cannibals]] and vampires are sexually aroused by eating human body parts. Category A, C, and F offenders may also cannibalize or drink the blood of their victims.<ref name=":0" />
==Research==
===Humans=== Necrophilia is often assumed to be rare, but no data for its prevalence in the general population exists.<ref>{{cite book | author = Milner, J. S., Dopke, C. A., & Crouch, J. L. | date= 2008 | title = Sexual Deviance: Theory, Assessment, and Treatment, 2nd edition | publisher = The Guilford Press | page = 399 | chapter = Paraphilia Not Otherwise Specified: Psychopathology and Theory | editor = Laws, D. Richard}}</ref> Some necrophiles only fantasize about the act, without carrying it out.<ref name="rosman" /> In 1958, Klaf and Brown commented that, although rarely described, necrophiliac [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.<ref name="klaf"/>
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed 122 cases of necrophilia. The sample was divided into genuine necrophiles, who had a persistent attraction to corpses, and pseudo-necrophiles, who acted out of opportunity, sadism, or transient interest. Of the total, 92% were male and 8% were female. 57% of the genuine necrophiles had occupational access to corpses, with morgue attendant, hospital orderly, and cemetery employee being the most common jobs. The researchers theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia:<ref name="rosman" /> #The necrophile develops poor [[self-esteem]], perhaps due in part to a significant loss; #:(a) They are very fearful of rejection by others and they desire a sexual partner who is incapable of rejecting them; and/or #:(b) They are fearful of the dead, and transform their fear—by means of [[reaction formation]]—into a desire. #They develop an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.
The authors reported that, of their sample of genuine necrophiles:<ref name="rosman" /> *68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner; *21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner; *15% by sexual attraction to dead people; *15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and *12% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse.
IQ data was limited, but not abnormally low. About half of the sample had a personality disorder, and 11% of true necrophiles were psychotic. Rosman and Resnick concluded that their data challenged the conventional view of necrophiles as generally psychotic, mentally deficient, or unable to obtain a consenting partner.<ref name="rosman" />
===Other animals=== [[File:Salvator merianae - necrophilia.jpg|thumb|290px|A male [[Argentine black and white tegu|black and white tegu]] mounts a female that has been dead for two days and attempts to mate.<ref name="sazima" />]] {{see also|Non-reproductive sexual behavior in animals}}
Necrophilia has been observed in mammals, birds, reptiles and frogs.<ref name="demattos">{{cite journal | author = de Mattos Brito, L. B., Joventino, I. R., Ribeiro, S. C., & Cascon, P. | year = 2012 | title = Necrophiliac behavior in the "cururu" toad, ''Rhinella jimi'' Steuvax, 2002, (Anura, Bufonidae) from Northeastern Brazil | journal = North-Western Journal of Zoology | volume = 8 | issue = 2 | page = 365 | url = http://biozoojournals.ro/nwjz/content/v8n2/nwjz.121206.Brito.pdf}}</ref> In 1960, Robert Dickerman described necrophilia in [[ground squirrel]]s, which he termed "Davian behavior" in reference to a [[limerick (poetry)|limerick]] about a necrophiliac miner named Dave. The label is still used for necrophilia in animals.<ref name="costa" /> Certain species of arachnids and insects practice [[sexual cannibalism]], in which the female cannibalizes her male mate prior to, during, or after copulation.
[[Kees Moeliker]] made one observation while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natural History Museum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead outside the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake pecked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes then mounted the corpse and began copulating with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior called "attempted [[rape]] flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback — well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243–247 |url=http://www.chm.bris.ac.uk/sillymolecules/papers/duck.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{cite news | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|author=Donald MacLeod | location=London | date=8 March 2005| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207231131/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2005/mar/08/highereducation.research| archivedate=2013-12-07 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Necrophilia had previously only been reported in heterosexual mallard pairs.<ref name="Mallard Duck" />
In a short paper known as "Sexual Habits of the Adélie Penguin", deemed too shocking for contemporary publication, [[George Murray Levick]] described "little hooligan bands" of penguins mating with dead females in the [[Cape Adare]] [[rookery]], the largest group of [[Adélie penguin]]s, in 1911 and 1912.<ref>{{cite news|last=McKie|first=Robin|title='Sexual depravity' of penguins that Antarctic scientist dared not reveal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/09/sex-depravity-penguins-scott-antarctic|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=9 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005160644/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/09/sex-depravity-penguins-scott-antarctic|archivedate=2013-10-05|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="russel">{{Cite journal | last1 = Russell | first1 = D. A male [[New Zealand sea lion]] was once observed attempting to copulate with a dead female [[New Zealand fur seal]] in the wild. The sea lion nudged the seal repeatedly, then mounted her and made several pelvic thrusts. Approximately ten minutes later, the sea lion became disturbed by the researcher's presence, dragged the corpse of the seal into the water and swam away while holding it.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Wilson, G. In 1983, a male [[rock dove]] was observed copulating with the corpse of a dove that had shortly before had its head crushed by a car.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Slavid, Evelyn |author2=Taylor, Julie | year = 1987 | title = Feral Rock Dove displaying to and attempting to copulate with corpse of another | journal = British Birds | volume = 8 | issue = 10 | page = 497 | url = http://www.britishbirds.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/article_files/V80/V80_N10/V80_N10_P492_502_N115.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/education/2005/mar/14/research.highereducation | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=14 March 2005}}</ref> In 2001, a researcher laid out [[sand martin]] corpses to attract flocks of other sand martins. This occurred one to two months after the breeding season; since copulation outside the breeding season is uncommon among birds, the researcher speculated that the lack of resistance by the corpses stimulated the behavior.<ref name="dale">{{cite journal | author = Dale, S. | year = 2001 | title = Necrophilic behaviour, corpses as nuclei of resting flock formation, and road-kills of Sand Martins ''Riparia riparia'' | journal = Ardea | volume = 89 | issue = 3 | pages = 545–547 | url = http://www.avibirds.com/pdf/O/Oeverzwaluw3.pdf}}</ref> Charles Brown observed at least ten [[cliff swallow]]s attempt to copulate with a road-killed cliff swallow in the space of 15 minutes. He commented, "This isn't the first time I've seen cliff swallows do this; the bright orange rump sticking up seems to be all the stimulus these birds need."<ref>{{cite book | author = Charles Robert Brown | year = 1998 | title = Swallow Summer | publisher = University of Nebraska Press | page = 143}}</ref> Necrophilia has also been reported in the [[European swallow]], [[grey-backed sparrow-lark]], [[Stark's lark]],<ref name="russel" /> and the [[snow goose]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = McKinney, F., & Evarts, S. | year = 1998 | title = Sexual coercion in waterfowl and other birds | journal = Ornithological Monographs | pages = 163–195 | doi = 10.2307/40166723}} The primary source ([https://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/condor/v093n03/p0701-p0711.pdf Gauthier & Tardif, 1991]) states that "a paired male attempted to mount a recently shot bird used to attract other geese."</ref> A Norwegian television report showed a male [[hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] between a [[black grouse]] and [[western capercaillie]] kill a male black grouse before attempting to copulate with it.<ref name="dale" /> In 2015, due to work done by the [[University of Washington]], it was found that [[crows]] would commit necrophilia on dead crow corpses in about 4% of encounters with corpses.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Yong |first=Ed |date=18 July 2018 |title=Crows Sometimes Have Sex With Their Dead |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2018/07/crow-necrophilia/565442/ |magazine= The Atlantic |publisher= |access-date=26 July 2018 }}</ref>
